comments.commentBody: pdurk's assertion is incorrect. Yes, it is true that the jobs will be lost through attrition (obviously - why would it make any economic sense at all to outright fire 2,000 people in a terrible economy?). However, "attrition" doesn't mean that Obama is making up the savings. It just means that they will accrue gradually over time, as people who retire are not replaced. The long-term savings (and their equivalent net present value) are still real.

Oh really? So is that why Sweden, Norway, Finland, Germany and Switzerland- all "Socialist" states with universal health care and low-cost education- have the most thriving export economies in the world, despite a lack of natural resources? And AAA ratings to boot? While the US (downgraded first) continues on a downward spiral with higher unemployment and wasted capital? Read the S&P report, Skep41- they clearly say the downgrades are due to overzealous austerity, i.e. LACK of govt. spending, as well as tax evasion, just as the US's downgrade came from austerity and the GOP's extremist opposition to any revenue increases. The opposite of what you conservatives contend. (Oh, and nice try taking a swipe at Obama, considering he inherited this mess from Republicans.)

The only successful modern countries are the mixed economies like the Scandinavians, Germans and Canadians, with a strong capitalistic export and innovation sector, but also state-supported education, research and infrastructure to make it work.

The fundamental problem is the either-or, simplistic thinking that you cite, especially from the conservative side. The country you want is Somalia- no "evil welfare state" there, no taxes, no "socialist" investment in schools, no healthcare or infrastructure. A capitalist market economy depends on the externalities of social investment to ensure a healthy, educated population not mired in debt and despair, a nuanced reality you refuse to accept.

"Oh really? So is that why Sweden, Norway, Finland, Germany and Switzerland- all "Socialist" states with universal health care and low-cost education- have the most thriving export economies in the world, despite a lack of natural resources?"

Because they have made necessary reforms and introduced flexibility into their systems. This is what France, Italy, Greece, and Spain refuse to do. Even in Denmark, they have restructured unemployment benefits so that the benefit goes down gradually after the first six months -- hint, hint, you'd better find a job!

However, in France, the unions fight for the right to live exactly the way they did forty years ago, only at a much higher rate.

Denmark's system works because there *are* jobs for people to take, as well as universal health care so that employees can take a variety of jobs - including contractors, freelancers and small business owners - and not worry about losing their health insurance or medical bankruptcy. Not so in US. There are people urgently seeking jobs that aren't there, and even if they do secure a job it often comes without health insurance, thus a clear and present danger to their financial well-being.

IOW, Denmark's job-encouragement policies work *because* it has a safety net and progressive, community-driven policies to ensure that workers are paid for their work and don't fall into economic hardship while in a bad patch.

In the US, the complete lack of any economic security, predatory health insurance companies and mass outsourcing of jobs, makes our own safety-net cutting even more counterproductive, producing a kind of serfdom class that's too demoralized to help the economy with their spending. They work far harder and contribute far more than any useless CEO with their golden parachutes for failing on the job, yet the corrupt US system continues to gut the very consumer class on which our economy depends.

France's public unions went overboard (the retirement age does need to go up given their health), but overall France has the same sensible policy as Germans and Danes - encourage people to work, and provide the regulations and safety nets to ensure they're rewarded for it.

This is not a problem caused by the investment community but a much larger problem caused by the European governments not being able to honor the extravagant promises of the welfare state. A very important aspect of these cradle-to-grave pensionocracies is the reluctance of their inhabitants to have children. Their populations are aging as the percentage of young people declines sharply. Add a 55 retirement age and this is what you get. Enterprise is strangled as taxes rise to try to meet the ever-expanding budgets of states filled with voters who demand ever-larger subsidies. This is the fall of the Soviet Union, Euro style. The US will be dragged down when the bond bubble bursts as our finances are approaching critical mass under the 'leadership' of The Worst President In American History and a political party that believes that unemployment checks and subsidies to labor unions stimulate the economy and who are about to embark on another round of digital money printing (QE 3) to try to buy reelection. The 'Great Social Experiment' ends a century later in national extinction.

Lem, the longest period of economic growth?  Yes, for the rich only.
Lem, perhaps the growth was do to government spending primarily on the military as the national debt tripled under Reagan.

We did not simply "allow" our high quality, first rate public schools to deteriorate -- we fell into the "trap" of believing that giving enormous power to a greedy and all-powerful union (teacher's union) would suddenly erase all social barriers, inequality, racial strife and produce a superior educational result.

If we could go back in time, you'd see all the pundits in 1970 or '75 telling you the problem (with a generally very good system) was "we don't pay teachers enough!" So we tripled and quadrupled teacher pay (adjusted for inflation!), and doubled and tripled what we pay per student (ditto).

The result of MORE MONEY without MORE OVERSIGHT & STANDARDS? Our educational system is now in the toilet -- high dropout rates, social promotions, kids who graduate unable to read and do math, violence in the schools -- and teachers who earn an average $80K a year for six hour day and all summer off with pay....and who can never, ever be fired.

The only "class warfare" that has been occurring in the US is by a very narrow wealthy elite that has so corrupted our political and economic systems that they fail to serve the interests of all of us.

In the post-WWII era, our economic and political systems created the largest stable middle class in the history of the planet. Thanks to a system that generated wealth through productive economic activity, and then ensured that such wealth benefited society as a whole through labor unions, progressive taxation, investment in infrastructure and public education, effective regulations, and a social safety net, we experienced unprecedented levels of economic opportunity and growth.

Then, starting in the early 1980s, we increasingly ditched that approach in favor of one that encouraged the increasing concentration of wealth at the top. We eviscerated labor unions, made our tax system far more regressive, allowed high quality public education systems to weaken, slashed the social safety net, and deregulated. And the result is the decline of the middle class, increased unemployment and deficits, and reduced economic growth, all so a very narrow wealthy elite could make out like bandits. To me, that was not a bargain worth making.
